column2: >In today s content-driven world, visuals are everything. Whether you're a real estate agent showcasing a luxury property, an interior designer highlighting your latest project, or a brand looking to tell a compelling story, photos play a huge role in how you present yourself.
column3: >But here's the catch, just because you paid for a photoshoot doesn t mean you own the photos. And that s where photo licensing comes in, a critical topic that often gets overlooked in our industry.
column4: >Let s break it down and keep it real.
column5: >What Is Photo Licensing, Anyway?
column6: >At 1 OAK Studios, when we deliver a gallery of final edits, what we re really giving you is a license, a legal agreement that allows you to use our images in specific ways, for specific purposes, over a defined period of time.
column7: >Photography, like music or software, is protected by copyright law. That means even though you paid us for the shoot, we (the creators) still own the rights to the images, unless otherwise specified in writing.
column8: >Think of it this way: Buying photos from us is like purchasing tickets to a concert. You get to enjoy the experience, but you don t own the music. The same goes for our visuals, you have the rights to use the photos under certain terms, but not to distribute or resell them unless that s been agreed upon ahead of time.
column9: ><strong>Why This Matters in Real Estate, Design &amp
column10: Branding
column11: >Let s get into a couple real-life examples to show how this applies:
column14: >A realtor hires us to shoot a high-end condo unit. Everything s clean, polished, ready to list. The agent posts the images online, and suddenly the developer wants to use the same photos in a national ad campaign.
column15: >But here s the issue: the agent s license doesn t automatically transfer to the developer. The developer would need to request usage rights from us (and likely pay an additional licensing fee) to legally use those images.
column18: >We photograph a stunning living room for an interior designer. Later, the designer shares those images with a furniture company whose products appear in the shots. The brand starts using them on social media and their website without asking us.
column19: >Unfortunately, even though their products appear in the photo, they still don t own the image. They need a separate license from us to use it legally.
column20: >These situations happen more often than you'd think and not because people are trying to do anything shady. It's usually just a lack of understanding around copyright and licensing.More Real-World Examples of Licensing Needs
column21: >A luxury home shoot for a realtor: After the listing goes live, the home builder, stager, or furniture vendor reaches out asking for the images. Even though they worked on the project, that doesn t mean they automatically get the photos. Licensing ensures everyone who benefits from the visuals compensates the creator fairly.
column22: >An interior design shoot: The cabinetry company, tile supplier, or lighting brand loves how their products look in the photos and they want to use them for their ads. Great! That s what licensing is for. But again, they ll need to pay for usage.
column23: >Commercial spaces: You shoot an office or restaurant for one client, and a contractor or architecture firm sees the images and wants to use them in their own portfolio. That s not free either. They need their own license.
column24: > Addressing the Misconception: We Provided Access, So We Own the Photos
column25: >We hear this one a lot, especially in luxury real estate:
column26: > Since we gave you access to this beautiful home, we should own the photos.
column27: >Let s clear that up. You hired us to professionally capture the space because of our skill, gear, and creative eye not just because we had access. Granting access is a part of the process, not the transaction. What you re paying for is our time, talent, and post-production, along with a license to use the final images not full ownership of them.
column28: >Ownership = copyright. And under U.S. copyright law, the creator (aka the photographer) holds the rights, unless we sign them away in writing which we don t. That s why licensing exists in the first place: to create a fair, flexible way to use images without handing over complete ownership. We ll Just Take It Down Isn t a Solution
column29: > If a photographer finds out we re using one of their images that we re not supposed to, we ll just take it down. Problem solved, right?
column31: >At that point, as the team at AP Almanac perfectly put it, the toothpaste is already out of the tube. The image has already been used without permission, and there s a good chance a license needs to be paid for, not just to resolve the situation, but to avoid more serious legal consequences.
column32: >As easy as it is to lift images online, it s just as easy for photographers to track unauthorized usage now. Tools like reverse image search, embedded metadata, and AI-based copyright trackers make it simple for creators to protect their work.
column33: >When a photo is used without a valid license, it s not just an oversight it s copyright infringement.
column34: >And unfortunately, we ve seen what often happens next:
column37: >Pretends they didn t know
column38: >Or just ignores it altogether
column39: >(Pro tip: Don t do any of those things.)
column40: >We re not here to hit you with legal threats. We re here to help you do it right, protect your business, and maintain good creative relationships. But the reality is, if a photographer has taken the steps to properly register their work and protect their rights, unauthorized use can lead to costly settlements sometimes in the thousands or even tens of thousands of dollars.
column42: >Before you use or share an image, ask yourself one simple question:
column43: >Do I have clear, written permission from the original photographer to use or distribute this image?
column44: >If not, the answer is easy: get permission. Licensing protects everyone and it s usually a lot more affordable than you think.
column45: >Best Practices to Stay Protected (and Professional)
column46: >To avoid accidentally crossing legal boundaries or ending up in a costly dispute, follow these key practices:
column47: > 1. Always Get Written Permission
column48: >If you want to share or distribute images beyond your original agreement (especially to third parties), always check in with us first. We re quick to respond, and most of the time we can work something out efficiently.
column49: > 2. Don t Assume Credit = Permission
column50: >Tagging a photographer on Instagram isn t a substitute for licensing. While we appreciate the shoutout, giving credit doesn t grant legal usage rights. Sometimes we see images that are ripped from the MLS (with terrible resolution) to the point that we don t even want the tag because of the super low quality res. making us and our clients look pretty bad.
column51: > 3. Understand Your License Terms
column52: >At 1 OAK Studios, we provide custom usage rights based on your needs whether that s for web, print, editorial, or large-scale campaigns. If you're unsure about what your license covers, just ask. We d rather clear things up on the front end.
column55: >If you're working with other brands, developers, or media outlets, let them know that the images are licensed not free for redistribution. If they re interested in using the images, send them our way. We handle licensing professionally and fairly.
column56: > Licensing Packages for Business Use
column57: >We know that great content gets noticed and we ve made it easy and affordable for businesses to legally license and use our work:
column58: >Social Media License $25/imageFor brands who want to repost our photos on platforms like Instagram, Facebook, LinkedIn, etc.Includes basic commercial use on social, but not website use.
column59: >Website License $50/image + yearly renewalPerfect for brands that want to showcase our images on their homepage, product pages, or blog.Licensing renews annually to keep things up-to-date and fair.
column60: >These options are designed to be accessible while protecting our work. So if we shoot a listing for a real estate agent, and a faucet company or countertop brand wants to use a stunning kitchen photo they can. Just the right way.
column61: > A Word to Fellow Photographers: Protect Your Work
column62: >If you re a creative in this space, listen up: don t give your work away. Just because someone paid you to shoot something doesn t mean they own your images unless you signed a full rights transfer (which you should almost never do).
column64: >If 5 businesses benefit from your photo, 5 businesses should pay for it.
column65: >Licensing ensures you re compensated not just once but for continued use.
column66: >It sets the tone that your work has value, and trains clients to respect the process.
column67: >Social tags don t pay the bills. Licensing does.
column68: >Don t be afraid to educate your clients. You re not being difficult you re being professional. Why We re Strict About This (And Why You Should Be Too)
column69: >We get it, licensing can feel like red tape. But here s the thing: our photos are our product. Just like you wouldn t give away your services for free, neither can we. Licensing allows us to maintain the quality, integrity, and value of what we create.
column70: >At 1 OAK Studios, we pride ourselves on delivering premium visual content at industry-leading speed (yes, that 24-hour turnaround is real). But just because we move fast doesn t mean we cut corners. Copyright matters. And respecting intellectual property keeps this whole creative ecosystem thriving.
column72: >So the next time you or someone you re working with wants to reuse, repost, or redistribute one of our photos take a second to make sure it s cool with us first. We re always here to help you do things the right way.

column74: >Let s keep your brand looking sharp and legit.

column2: >Where can I see pricing?
column3: >Booking with 1 OAK Studios is quick and hassle-free. Here s how it works:
column4: >1 Book Online or Contact Us Use our online booking portal to schedule your shoot, or reach out via phone, email, or text for custom requests. booking@1oakstudios.com 786.509.9992 mon - fri 10am - 6pm
column5: >2 Confirm Details We ll confirm the date, time, location, and any special requests. If property access needs coordination (lockbox, agent on-site, etc.), let us know in advance.
column6: >3 Shoot Day Our team arrives on time and ready to capture stunning visuals. Make sure the space is clean and staged for the best results!
column7: >Where do I cancel or reschedule a project?
column8: >You can reach our office at 786.509.9992 from Monday to Friday, 10 AM to 6 PM, or email us at booking@1oakstudios.com. For rescheduling, please use your portal account to make changes at least 24 hours before your appointment. Cancellations or rescheduling on the same day or made late will incur a $50 fee. Any applicable travel fees will be charged in addition to the cancellation fee for same-day, late, or on-site cancellations.
column9: >How do I prepare for my appointment?
column10: >Your expectations of working with us means that you want the absolute best, In return we expect the same from our clients. It s the client s responsibility to ensure that the property is ready at the arranged time. please view our pre-shoot checklist
column11: >To ensure a smooth and efficient experience, clients are responsible for:
column12: >Property Access Providing clear instructions for entry (lockbox codes, gate access, on-site contact, etc.). If we can t access the property at the scheduled time, a rescheduling fee may apply.
column14: Permissions Ensuring all necessary permissions from the property owner are secured before the shoot. please read PROPERTY OWNER APPROVAL &
column16: >Clear Communication Providing accurate details, special requests, and any changes before the scheduled appointment to avoid delays.
column17: >By handling these details in advance, we can focus on delivering top-tier visuals fast and hassle-free!
column18: >How long will it take to receive media?
column19: >Creating high-quality content takes time. Depending on the services requested, 1 OAK Studios typically needs 1-4 hours on-site. Any delays on-site may impact the production schedule and final delivery time.
column20: >Below is our standard turnaround time for each service:
column23: >Professional Photos 3 business days (Homes over 8,000+ sqft or requiring extra detail may take longer to ensure quality)
column24: >Luxury / Architectural / Interior Design Photos 4 business days (Project timelines vary based on complexity)
column25: >Twilight / Virtual Twilight Photos 48 hours
column26: >Virtual Staging Photos 2-3 business days (Third-party processing involved)
column30: >1-2 min Cinematic Videos 2-3 business days
column31: >1-3 min Luxury Videos 3-5 business days
column32: >Creative Projects 7-15 business days (Timeline varies based on complexity)
column34: >2D Floor Plans 1 business day
column35: >3D Virtual Tours (Matterport) 1 business day
column36: >3D Matterport Virtual Tours include free hosting for 3 months.
column37: >After 3 months, 3D Matterport Virtual Tours will be archived and the branded and unbranded links will no longer be active.
column38: >Extra hosting is available for $60 for another 3 months.
column39: >Dedicated Property Websites 24 hours (After all content is created)
column40: >Photo Revision Requests 1 business day ($10/photo, object removal fees apply)
column41: >Video Revision Requests 1-2 business days (One complimentary revision
column44: > Rush Edits (Subject to Availability)
column45: >Photo Rush Delivery Starts at $100 (Consultation required before the shoot)
column46: >Video Rush Delivery Starts at $250 (Consultation required before the shoot)
column47: >How can I get something edited or revised?
column48: >Please contact our support team with the same email you received your deliverables. make sure to give a detailed description. booking@1oakstudios.com or call our support line 786.509.9992 ext #2 some requests may be subject to an additional fee.
column49: >What rights do I have with the media provided?
column50: >1 OAK Studios grants the Client a limited license to use the Work Product (photos, videos, and other media) for the promotion of the listing and personal marketing purposes. The Client may upload the content to: Social media Personal websites MLS listing services Portfolio use for lead generation and soliciting new business
column51: >However, this license does not transfer copyright, ownership, or any exclusive rights to the Client. Regardless of MLS terms and conditions, all intellectual property rights remain with 1 OAK Studios, in accordance with Copyright Act 17 U.S.C 106.
column52: >Any third-party use or redistribution (e.g., magazines, design firms, or new listing agents) requires written permission from 1 OAK Studios and may be subject to licensing fees.
